Well, in web developement, a complex process rarely leads to a simple product.
should we take the "initial" meaning of KISS (Keep It Simple, Stupid), with a comma before the "Stupid", to mean that it's just an interjection (something like "Keep It Simple, you moron ...)
The smart part is about realizing what you need. (Sometimes you can find “smart” solutions that solve complex problems in simple and elegant ways, but that should not be your priority.)

To be smart about something, you need to know a lot about it, or to think or research quite a bit. That part, the design part, can be complex sometimes. Even if it’s a seemingly simple “best practice” (one that you can write in one clear sentence), you need to know things in depths to be sure it’s actually a good practice that you can apply most of the time. Or you need to trust that somebody smarter than you are (about this topic) has done the thinking and research.
On the other hand, avoiding necessary complexity is not smart. :)
twitter is incredibly simple, but the architecture is not that simple :)
A nice thing about “Keep it simple & *smart*” as a topic is that it allows for this discussion. I’m sure it’ll find some echos in the presentations.

Avoiding unnecessary complexity is smart. When the complexity (or part of it) is simply a hindrance on your users (end users of a GUI, developers using an API, etc.) then it’s a smart move to reduce the complexity wherever it’s not justified.

If I compare the evolution of classic web app design (including frameworks such as django, RoR, symfony, etc.) they tend to become complex (in their use and in their implementation). For me, CouchDB is really smart because it offers a simple solution by using web standards. The same thing for SOAP vs REST. Finally, it appears that you need to have experience and knowledge to build efficient things because they are simple, which can be taken for smartness.
being smart may be needed to write simple code, but if you write smart code, you definitely need to be smart to read it
being smart, and writing/coding smart are two different things i believe

When it comes to implementing the idea or design or best practice, the implementation can be simple or complex. Depends. I tend to prefer best practices or design patterns that call for simple implementations, probably because I’m lazy — but also because it means you can go back easily if the idea proves itself wrong.
and (own experience), writing smart code doesn't mean you can easily read it and understand it later on. I personaly believe that this is what it's about when talking about SIMPLE and STUPID

j'en reviens toujours à ma première réaction à l'enoncé du sujet… chaque personne a en tête sa propre perception de cette notion de simplicité, de complexité, et qu'il ne faut pas passer sous silence la démarche, les objectifs, l'intentionnalité de leur mise en oeuvre (simplification vs. mamouthisation anyone?)

par exemple, l'usage de la métaphore dans l'agilité est souvent perçu par les débutants comme un truc de poètes frustrés, alors que c'est un moyen de rendre la communication possible sur des notions parfois extrêmement complexes

par contre, vouloir simplifier une relation au travers d'un rapport hiérarchique établi de fait, par ex., est un mauvais exemple de simplification mal outillée, mal comprise et aux résultats très aléatoires
